item.title: Two rare blue lobsters caught in Canada
item.description:
Fishermen off the coast of Canada have nabbed some rare treasures.

Sponsored:

Do NOT pay your next car insurance bill until you try this.
item.ExtractedText:
Facebook Twitter Instagram
Two rare blue lobsters caught in Canada Updated 2110 GMT (0510 HKT) May 24, 2016 JUST WATCHED Rare blue lobster caught off the coast of Canada 02:04 Story highlights The chances of nabbing a blue lobster are one in 2 million A gene mutation creates this unique coloring phenomenon (CNN) Fishermen off the coast of Canada have nabbed some rare treasures. In the past week, two blue lobsters that look like they should be in a science-fiction movie were discovered in the waters off Alder Point, Nova Scotia. Lifelong fisherman Blaine Marsh made the first crustacean discovery, and his granddaughter got to name the sea critter. She dubbed the lobster Blueberry. "It's a good luck sign for the fisherman. I hope the fisherman have a good season this lobster season." Marsh's wife, Mary Marsh, told CNN's affiliate CTV . Marsh released the lobster back in the ocean on Sunday. Then on Monday, Scott MacKinnon caught a second blue lobster about 93 miles away near Low Point, Nova Scotia. Read More The distance between the two spots means there's no way it's the same lobster, MacKinnon told CTV. Besides, he said, "their lobster was undersized and ours was a pound and a half." So how unique are these blue critters? About one in 2 million have a special gene mutation that affects their coloring, according to the University of Maine Lobster Institute . This phenomenon produces high levels of protein that give the crustaceans their bright azure hue. MacKinnon named his lobster Opal, and plans to keep it in a tank until the end of lobster season, which is July 14. "The old people say it's good luck and prosperity for the boat. No chance on eating it, no. We're going to send the good luck back to the ocean," he said. JUST WATCHED
